io.robusta.rra.utils

Class StringUtils

  • java.lang.Object
    • io.robusta.rra.utils.StringUtils

  • public class StringUtils
extends java.lang.Object
    This class gives a few function to waork on Strings.

    Most importants are probably

    • validateEmail()
    • replaceAny()
    • removeCharacters()

    Created by Nicolas Zozol for Robusta Code
    Author:
    Nicolas Zozol TODO : verify this class is GWT compatible TODO : check if any is NOT used inside the library

      static java.lang.String normalize(java.lang.String string, java.lang.String specifiedJoints)
      Transfom joints in capital characters Chateau De Versailles => ChateauDeVersaille white_house => whiteHouse (House is now capitalized) groovyStyle_grails => groovyStyleGrails (inside capitals are untouched) One difference with Java style is that the first letter might stay a capital If specifiedJoints == null, the method uses default ones : " _-", thought this can be changed with the defaultJoints

      Removes in the string every characters inside charactersToRemove.
      For exemple removeCharacters("Napoleon","nou") returns Naple because it will remove one 'n', two 'o' and zero 'u'
      Like for removeCharacter(String string, char c), the original String is not modified.

    • Method Detail

      • validateEmail

        public static boolean validateEmail(java.lang.String email)
        This function test if an email is valid. It's not the best validation of the world : all good emails will pass, but some wrong emails (even if it's very unlikely) may also pass.

        This function is based on the Javascript pattern /^([a-zA-Z0-9_.-])+@([a-zA-Z0-9_.-])+\.([a-zA-Z])+([a-zA-Z])+/

        Check IETF for more informations.

        Parameters:
        email - email to be tested
        Returns:
        true if email is an email pattern, false if not
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the email is null

      • validateMD5

        public static boolean validateMD5(java.lang.String md5String)
        Returns true if the String could be a md5
        Parameters:
        md5String - String to test : could it be a MD5, or there is no way ?
        Returns:
        true if the String could be a md5
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the md5String is null

        public static java.lang.String getEmailPrefix(java.lang.String email)

        Returns what is before the '@' character. For nicolas.zozol@robustaweb.com email, we'll get here nicolas.zozol

        Throws:

      • removeCharacter

        public static java.lang.String removeCharacter(java.lang.String string,
                               char c)

        removes a character in the String

        String boss="Bruce Springsteen";
        String result = StringUtils.removeCharacter(boss, 'e') returns "Bruc Springstn".
        But the original String boss is not modified.

        Parameters:
        string -
        c -
        Returns:

      • removeCharacters

        public static java.lang.String removeCharacters(java.lang.String original,
                                java.lang.String charactersToRemove)

        Removes in the string every characters inside charactersToRemove.
        For exemple removeCharacters("Napoleon","nou") returns Naple because it will remove one 'n', two 'o' and zero 'u'
        Like for removeCharacter(String string, char c), the original String is not modified.

        It's a recursive function, not the fastest you may have.

        Parameters:
        original - Original string
        charactersToRemove - characters that will be removed form the Original String
        Returns:
        a new string without the specified characters
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if original or charactersToRemove is null

      • removeStartingCharacters

        public static java.lang.String removeStartingCharacters(java.lang.String originalString,
                                        char character)
        Will remove all characters from the end.

        removeStartingCharacters(iiiiMalagi, 'i') returns Malagi

        If the string is empty, it returns also an empty string. If the string is null, it will throw a IllegalArgumentException
        Parameters:
        originalString - Original parameter
        character -
        Returns:
        Removes all the specified character found at the beginning of the string
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - : if the string is null

      • removeTrailingCharacters

        public static java.lang.String removeTrailingCharacters(java.lang.String originalString,
                                        char character)
        Will remove all characters from the end.

        removeTrailingCharacters(Malagaaaa, 'a') returns Malag

        If the string is empty, it returns also an empty string. If the string is null, it will throw a IllegalArgumentException
        Parameters:
        originalString - Original parameter
        character -
        Returns:
        Removes all the specified character found at the end of the string
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - : if the string is null

      • replaceSequence

        public static java.lang.String replaceSequence(java.lang.String originalString,
                               java.lang.String sequenceToReplace,
                               java.lang.String replacement)

        This is a simpler alternative to original String.replaceAll function that uses complex Regexp. Here, you modify a String by changing the characters sequence sequenceToReplace by the replacement string.

        Exemple :
         String original = "//cooluri//living.js///";
        Then
         StringUtils.replaceAll(original,"//", "-");
        will return :
        -cooluri-living.js-/

        Note that the '///' is always seen as ('//'+'/') and never as ('/'+'//'). This function is sequential, and will not always work like regular expressions.

        Parameters:
        originalString - The original string
        sequenceToReplace - The characters sequence to replace
        replacement -
        Returns:
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if a param is null

      • replaceAny

        public static java.lang.String replaceAny(java.lang.String originalString,
                          java.lang.String anyCharacter,
                          java.lang.String replacement)
        Replace any character defined in anyCharacter by a replacement sequence Ex : 
         replaceAny("john jack jim", "ji", "t") => "tohn tack ttm"
        Parameters:
        originalString -
        anyCharacter -
        replacement -
        Returns:

      • truncate

        public static java.lang.String truncate(java.lang.String original,
                        int number)

        Keeps the 'number' first characters, and might be useful to keep your user's privacy :
         truncate("Hernandez", 3)
        will produce: "Her"

        If number is bigger than the size of the String, the whole string is kept :
         truncate("Hernandez", 24)
        will produce: "Hernandez"

        If number==0, the function returns an empty string.

        Parameters:
        original -
        number -
        Returns:
        a new smaller String.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if number<0 or original is null

        Parameters:

        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if charactersToTest is null or empty

        Parameters:

      • split

        public static java.lang.String[] split(java.lang.String string,
                       java.lang.String separatorChars)
        TODO 1 : work on this ; Use StringTokenizer

        Splits the provided text into an array ,* separators specified.

        The separator is not included in the returned String array. Adjacent separators are treated as one separator. 

         StringUtils.split("ab de fg", " ")   = ["ab", "de", "fg"]
 StringUtils.split("ab   de fg", " ") = ["ab", "cd", "ef"]
 StringUtils.split("ab:cd:ef", ":")    = ["ab", "cd", "ef"]
        Parameters:
        string - the String to parse, may be null
        separatorChars - the characters used as the delimiters
        Returns:
        an array of parsed Strings
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if string or separatorChars is null, or if separatorChars is empty

      • normalize

        public static java.lang.String normalize(java.lang.String string,

        Transfom joints in capital characters Chateau De Versailles => ChateauDeVersaille white_house => whiteHouse (House is now capitalized) groovyStyle_grails => groovyStyleGrails (inside capitals are untouched) One difference with Java style is that the first letter might stay a capital If specifiedJoints == null, the method uses default ones : " _-", thought this can be changed with the defaultJoints
        Parameters:
        string -
        Returns:
